label: Flying shuttle patented (John Kay)
summary_short: John Kay’s flying shuttle sped up weaving and increased demand for spun yarn, helping trigger later spinning innovations.

label: Bridgewater Canal opens (coal transport to Manchester)
summary_short: The Bridgewater Canal opened to move coal efficiently, cutting transport costs and accelerating industrial growth.

label: Spinning jenny invented (James Hargreaves)
summary_short: A multi-spindle spinning machine that greatly increased yarn output and helped propel mechanized textile production.

label: Water frame patented (Richard Arkwright)
summary_short: Arkwright’s water frame used rollers and water power to spin stronger yarn, supporting large-scale mills.

label: Watt’s separate condenser patented (steam engine efficiency)
summary_short: James Watt’s separate condenser greatly improved steam engine efficiency, enabling broader industrial use beyond mines.

label: Spinning jenny patented (James Hargreaves)
summary_short: Hargreaves secured a patent for the spinning jenny, helping spread multi-spindle spinning as textile production mechanized.

label: Cromford Mill uses water frame (early factory system)
summary_short: Arkwright’s water-powered spinning at Cromford is often cited as a key step toward the factory system in textiles.

label: Spinning mule invented (Samuel Crompton)
summary_short: Crompton’s spinning mule combined features of earlier spinning machines and enabled large-scale production of high-quality yarn.

label: Power loom patented (Edmund Cartwright)
summary_short: Cartwright’s power loom mechanized weaving, helping shift textile production further into factories.

label: Cotton gin invented (Eli Whitney)
summary_short: Whitney’s cotton gin sped seed removal, expanding raw cotton supply feeding textile mills and intensifying the global cotton economy.

label: Penydarren steam locomotive run (Trevithick)
summary_short: A landmark early rail journey powered by a steam locomotive, demonstrating the feasibility of steam traction on rails.

label: Rainhill Trials won by Stephenson’s Rocket
summary_short: Rocket’s success at the Rainhill Trials helped convince investors and engineers that locomotive-hauled railways were viable at scale.

label: Factory Act (UK) strengthens child labor regulation and enforcement
summary_short: The 1833 Factory Act restricted child labor and created an inspectorate—an important step toward enforceable workplace regulation.

label: Great Exhibition opens in London (Crystal Palace)
summary_short: A major international exhibition showcasing industrial and cultural achievements, symbolizing Britain’s industrial prominence.

label: Bessemer process patented (mass steel production)
summary_short: Bessemer’s process enabled cheaper mass production of steel, accelerating industrial expansion in railways, construction, and machinery.
